text: Family Member: Hi. Nice to see you. Doctor: So, you know, you done good. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: How about that? Family Member: Good news. No new treatments. Doctor: Yeah. I think you get a break for six weeks until I torture you with that, I mean help you, again. Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But some protocols do. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So those are just nuance of that type of escalation. Uh. You --- it would be a window. So, it would be something that again if you’re trying to avoid chemotherapy, here’s something that I could try. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s, uh, uh, the third option of a trial, so, is chemotherapy plus vitamin C, a phase one study. The other study would be that we would have to check a blood test on you, uh, that if you came back as AR-V7 positive. And I’d have to see if we’ve already done that for you in the past. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may have at the start of this study. Uh, uh, and it can change with therapy. So, you would have to repeat it again. Um, and you’ve had Enzalutamide, so I think you’d be good to go on that one. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that you actually would stay on the Enzalutamide and if you’re AR-V7 positive, well then we have, uh, some of the new list of new therapies that are being used in other tumor types. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, we’re looking to see what they’re likelihood of benefiting men with prostate cancer are.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: - with this kind of cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We would say forget why are we even bothering to putting you in harm’s way or side effects way – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - by trying to just take care of the prostate when everything else is out there. Patient: Right. Doctor: But given that you don’t have anything else visible and all these years you haven’t had anything evolve. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this is the only area, I am thinking it’s worthwhile considering the cryo procedure. Okay? Patient: The whole thing or is this a partial? Doctor: Well no I think almost all of the prostate will need to be cryoed. So that’s why I figure Dr. C____ should come in and talk to you. Explain the details of the procedure and he’s saying that urinary leakage and everything chances are about one in four after the procedure, but that’s the risk we take and remember we talked about that that you know do we want to take that leakage risk. But given what I’m seeing is it’s that or wait until the prostate gland blocks your urinary flow which is not a good outcome at all. Right, yeah. If that wasn’t such an immediate threat, then I would have said no just sit tight, don’t do anything. Patient: Right.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
